Biography

Abstract

Niels Bohr was a theoretical nuclear physicist at Copenhagen University. He created the Bohr atomic model. In 1922, he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics "for his services in the investigation of the structure of atoms and of the radiation emanating from them."

October 7, 1885Birth, Copenhagen (Denmark).

1906Awarded Gold Medal, Royal Danish Academy of Sciences (Kongelige Danske videnskabernes selskab), Copenhagen (Denmark).

1906Obtained Master's degree in Physics, Copenhage University (Københavns universitet), Copenhagen (Denmark).

1911Obtained PhD in Physics, Copenhagen University (Københavns universitet), Copenhagen (Denmark).

1911 – 1912Researcher, Cavendish Laboratory, Cambridge (England).

1912 – 1962Researcher (1912-1913); Assistant Professor in Physics (1913); Professor of Theoretical Physics (1916); Head, Department of Theoretical Physics (1920-1962); and Director, Institute of Theoretical Physics (1921-1962), Copenhagen University (Københavns universitet), Copenhagen (Denmark).

1913Introduced Bohr Model of Atom with Ernest Rutherford, Victoria University of Manchester, Manchester (England).

1914 – 1916Professor of Physics, Victoria University of Manchester, Manchester (England).

1917 – 1962Fellow (1917) and President (1939-1962), Royal Danish Academy of Sciences (Kongelige Danske videnskabernes selskab), Copenhagen (Denmark).

1918Wrote "On the Quantum Theory of Line Spectra".

1920Established Institute of Theoretical Physics (Niels Bohr Institute), University of Copenhagen (Københavns universitet), Copenhagen (Denmark).

1921Awarded Hughes Medal, Royal Society.

1922Awarded Nobel Prize in Physics "for his services in the investigation of the structure of atoms and of the radiation emanating from them".

1922Wrote "The Theory of Spectra and Atomic Constitution".

1923Awarded Matteucci Medal.

1923 – 1962Foreign member, Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences (Koninklijke Nederlandse Akademie van Wetenschappen).

1926Awarded Franklin Medal.

1926 – 1962Foreign member, Royal Society.

1934Wrote "Atomic Theory and the Description of Nature".

1938Awarded Copley medal.

1943 – 1945Consultant, Manhattan Project, Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory under pseudonym Nicholas Baker, Los Alamos (N.M.).

1950Wrote "Open Letter to the United Nations".

1954Helped establish European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN).

1955Wrote "The Unity of Knowledge".

1955Organized Atoms for Peace Conference, Geneva (Switzerland).

1955Wrote "The Unity of Knowledge".

1955 – 1956Established (1955) and Chairman (1956), Danish Atomic Energy Commision (Research Establishment Risø), Roskilde (Denmark).

1957Chairman, Nordic Institute for Theoretical Physics (Nordisk institut for teoretisk atomfysik; NORDITA), Stockholm (Sweden).

1957Awarded Atoms for Peace Award.

November 18, 1962Death, Copenhagen (Denmark).

Occupation

Theoretical nuclear physicist.
